overview: The purpose of this measure is to repeal the requirement that a provider-patient relationship be established in person for purposes of obtaining a certification for medical cannabis. [7] The legislature finds that registration for the medical cannabis program has decreased in the last few years, with the number of patients decreasing over fifteen per cent from a peak in August 2021 to November 2024. [6] This Act repeals the requirement that a provider-patient relationship be established in person and has been amended to require that written certifications originate from within the State. [6] [6]
agency_impact: The Department of Health (DOH) recommended amending chapter 329, HRS, to limit medical cannabis certifications to those that “shall originate from within the State.” [5] This recommendation was incorporated into the bill as amended by the Committee on Consumer Protection & Commerce. [7] The committee also deleted language that allowed applicants to temporarily purchase medical cannabis, which addresses previous concerns from the DOH and the Department of the Attorney General regarding potential liability, patient arrests, and inventory inaccuracies. [7] [5] [5] [5]
economic_impact: The number of registered medical cannabis patients reached its peak in August 2021, with 35,444 card-holding patients, but has since decreased over fifteen per cent to 30,035 by November 2024. [6] Testimony states that enrollment in December of 2024 hit a low of 29,882 participants, the lowest since 2020. [5] Barriers to access include limited physician participation, with only 237 physicians and APRNs registered as of December 2024, and the uninsured cost of a medical cannabis card, which can range from $100.00 (HB302_HD1_TESTIMONY_CPC_02-06-25_.PDF.txt) to $300.00 (HB302_HD1_TESTIMONY_CPC_02-06-25_.PDF.txt) plus a $38.50 (HB302_HD1_TESTIMONY_CPC_02-06-25_.PDF.txt) state fee. [5] [5]
policy_impact: This measure repeals the requirement that a provider-patient relationship be established in person for the purpose of obtaining a medical cannabis certification. [7] A significant policy change from the previous version of the bill is the deletion of language that would have allowed applicants or primary caregivers to temporarily purchase medical cannabis after submitting a certification form. [7] The measure was also amended to add a new requirement that all written certifications for medical cannabis must originate from within the State. [7] [6]
revenue_sources: Testimony provided notes that the Medical Cannabis Registry Program currently has about $11.6M in the registry special fund. [5]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The most significant update is a major policy change in the bill, which now deletes the language that allowed applicants to temporarily purchase medical cannabis after submitting a certification form. [7] This amendment addresses the primary concerns about liability and operational issues previously raised by the Department of the Attorney General and the Department of Health. [5] [5] A new policy requirement has been added, specifying that written certifications for medical cannabis must originate from within the State. [7] [6] New and more specific data on the decline in registered patients is now available, showing a decrease from 35,444 in August 2021 to 30,035 by November 2024. [6] Additionally, testimony has identified a revenue source, noting that the Medical Cannabis Registry Program has approximately $11.6M in its special fund. [5]
